notesStmt.note: Discusses the trial of William Anderton, tried for high treason, after being accused of printing two pamphlets: "Remarks upon the present confederacy and the late revolution in England" and "A French conquest neither desirable nor practicable". He was sentenced to death and executed at Tyburn on June 16th, 1693. -- Cf. Plomer.

Includes "To the Right Honourable Sir John Fleet, Lord Mayor of the City of London, and the rest of the commissioners for the Goal delivery of Newgate. The humble petition of William Anderton a convicted prisoner in Newgate.".

div.head: An Appeal of Murther from certain unju≈øt Judges, lately ≈øitting at the Old Baily, to the righteous Judge of Heaven and Earth; and to all ≈øen≈øible Engli≈øh-men, containing a Relation of the Tryal, Behaviour, and Death of Mr. William Anderton, Executed June 16. 1693. at Tyburn, for pretended High-Trea≈øon.
div.p:
WEre all Men truly Good, publick Laws would be of little or no u≈øe. For all political Laws are the good Daughter of a bad Mother, as being preventionally or occa≈øionally the Off-≈øpring of ill Manners; but without them there is no Living in any Comfort or Security: hence all civilized Nations have ever gloried in their Laws, as their Honour and Safety, and heretofore none more than the Engli≈øh, and perhaps none with greater rea≈øon; for it may be a difficult Task for a well-read Hi≈øtorian to find out a Kingdom under the Cope of Heaven, where the Lives, Liberties, and Properties of Subjects are more cautiou≈øly and critically ≈øecured; but e≈øpecially in ca≈øe of Life (the Foundation of all humane Ble≈ø≈øings) wherein no Conjectures or Pre≈øumptions are allowed, but the Law requires at lea≈øt two credible and po≈øitive Witne≈ø≈øes, and if any thing be doubtful or controverted, always judgeth in favorem vite, and makes even the Judg him≈øelf of Councel to the Pri≈øoner, that he may by no means mi≈øcarry through any Error, Ignorance, Pa≈ø≈øion, or Inadvertency. But after all, the Law is a dead Letter, and cannot execute it ≈øelf; and when it ≈øo happens, that the Laws, which were made again≈øt Offences, are ≈øeized by the Offenders, and turned again≈øt tho≈øe whom they were de≈øigned to protect, the Sins of any Nation can ≈øcarce draw upon them a more heavy Cur≈øe and Judgment: For then the Sheep are daily dragg'd to tryal before the Wolf, and nothing but Villany is maintain'd, encouraged,
and promoted; and an hone≈øt Man had a thou≈øand times better fall into the hands of a Confederacy of High-way-men, who will rob and di≈øpatch him with ≈øome kind of Genero≈øity, than under the clutches of a corrupt Mini≈øter of Law, who after a ≈øwinging mortification in a na≈øty Pri≈øon, ≈øhall at length in a great deal of ≈øtate, with mighty formality, and tedious ceremony, proudly doom him to death, and all under colour and pretence of tho≈øe Laws, which, if they could ≈øpeak for them≈øelves, would acquit the Pri≈øoner and hang the Judge; and whether the following ca≈øe be not a fre≈øh and lamentable In≈øtance of ≈øomething too like this, I ≈øhall leave wholly to the Readers Judgment, after an impartial Peru≈øal.

Mr. William Anderton knowing him≈øelf to be mortally, though caule≈øly hated, by ≈øome Per≈øons, had ab≈øconded of late for a con≈øiderable time, as it has been the hard fortune of divers great and good Men to do in the≈øe difficult times; but being by a parcel of fal≈øe Villains betrayed to Mr. Robert Stephens, Me≈ø≈øenger of the Pre≈øs, and his ≈øworn Enemy, he was apprehended on the ≈øecond of May this pre≈øent 1693. and Stephens (who≈øe Malice much out-weighs his Brains) not content with his Per≈øon, plainly plundered the Hou≈øe, carrying away Goods to a con≈øiderable Value, which there was no colour of Law for him or any Man el≈øe to ≈øeize; and this I ≈øuppo≈øe might be one great motive, to make him ≈øwear ≈øo de≈øperately at the Tryal, that he might take away a Man's Life, who otherwi≈øe might come upon him for Robbing him of his Goods; the Booty ≈øecured, away he goes, in triumph with his Pri≈øoner, to my Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Holt, where he railed again≈øt him in a very indecent manner; the Judge was very calm, and ≈øaid very little to the matter, but, upon the accu≈øation, committed Mr. Anderton to Newgate, not for High Trea≈øon as is fal≈øely alledged, by that Lying Pamphleteer, licen≈øed according to Order, who publi≈øhed that malicious Account of his Conver≈øation, Behaviour and Execution which was cryed about Streets immediately after his death; That Judge knew the Law better, and I believe is not in him≈øelf ≈øo very forward
to over≈øtrain it. Whil≈øt he thus ≈øtood committed for Mi≈ødemeanour, he was bailable; and accordingly very ≈øufficient Bail was offered for him; but Aaron Smith, who wi≈øely weighs what advantage is to be made of every Pri≈øoner, and con≈øiders not only the Per≈øon him≈øelf, but the Intere≈øt he is engaged in, and the Friends he may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have, thought too few Guineas were offered; and therefore ≈øtill kept off the Bail endeavouring to make a better Market; but while things hung thus between the Bail and the Bail-ma≈øter, on a ≈øuddain the Controver≈øy was ended by the coming of a fre≈øh Warrant upon the former, which committed the Pri≈øoner for High Trea≈øon.

This way of Proceeding being ≈øomewhat unu≈øual gave occa≈øion to divers Cen≈øures; ≈øome ≈øaid, it was only a Trick to prevent his being bayled: others ≈øaid, that the Fact, though never ≈øo fully proved, could not amount to High Trea≈øon, and that they could not touch his Life; and that they had hereby done him a Kindne≈øs, becau≈øe upon his Tryal he would be di≈øcharged without any further Impri≈øonment or Corporal Puni≈øhment: But the≈øe, I ≈øuppo≈øe, were more conver≈øant among the Lawyers than the Politicians, and could better tell what ought to be done, than what ≈øome Men were contriving to do. Others judg'd this fre≈øh Commitment to be the re≈øult of new Councels, and a plain Evidence, that they had taken new Mea≈øures; and therefore did hence conclude, that he was thought a Per≈øon not only dangerous, but fit to make an Example, and that therefore it was re≈øolved he ≈øhould be hanged right or wrong: And the Event proved the≈øe to be in the right.

Now ≈øuch illegal Proceedings and bloody Councels very ill becomes tho≈øe who complained of ≈ømaller Failings in others, and have turned all things up≈øide down under a pretence to mend Matters and reform Abu≈øes; but there is nothing more ≈øanguinary, than a pretending State-Reformer; nothing more cruel and ≈øavage, than a Moderation-Man got into Power. But the≈øe doings being naturally ≈øo odious to Engli≈øh men, I hope they will con≈øider,
that the difference is not great, whether they be hanged with Popi≈øh or Prote≈øtant Halters; and will ≈øee at la≈øt, that they have a very ill ≈øecurity for their Lives, Liberties, and Properties, when tho≈øe who take upon them to guard them from Popery, become more Lawle≈øs and Cruel than Papi≈øts. There were indeed ≈øome even in the Councel who did di≈ølike the≈øe Proceedings: but others prevailed; and it would not be forgotten, that there is a certain ≈øly plump Divine, who perhaps is as good at Hocus Pocus Tricks, as any Man in Europe; he can cut a Man's Throat ≈øo neatly, that he ≈øhall never know who hurt him; he will put at his plea≈øure all into confu≈øion and hurry, make Men ≈øo mad that they know not where they are, nor care what Mi≈øchief they do; and all the while, as if he had Gyges's Ring, ≈øhall walk invi≈øible, and ≈øhall not be ≈øo much as ≈øu≈øpected to have had any hand in the matter: To this Crafts-Ma≈øter Robin Stephens made ha≈øte over the Water to ≈øet forth his great Services, and to receive ample Prai≈øes, if not a Reward. But his Expectation was ≈øadly baulk'd; for the Oracle fell foul upon him, telling him, that now he was threatened to be turn'd out of his Place he could find the≈øe Men, and that it might ju≈øtly be thought that he had been confederate with them all this while, and fal≈øe to the Government; and that if he did not give better Te≈øtimony of his good affection to the Government, and that he was an Enemy to ≈øuch kind of Men, he might lo≈øe his Place for all this. Now all this is only an U≈øe of In≈øtruction to a Me≈ø≈øenger who was malicious enough of him≈øelf; for the plain Engli≈øh of it is this; 'Tis true you have taken a Printer, but what of that? For unle≈øs you go through with your Work, and ≈øwear him out of his Life, you do the Government no Service, and had as good have done nothing at all: Guilt is ever mercile≈øs and bloody, a Man is got into the head of a Schi≈øm, has ≈øeiz'd on N ‚Ä¢
bath's Vineyard, and there wanted not much but they had kill'd to ≈øecure the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; for had not Fuller's Plot mi≈øcarried we had had a Jezebel's Fa≈øt, and Sons of Belial had been ≈øet up to te≈øtify, that the poor old innocent Gentleman did bla≈øphemy God „Äà‚óä„Äâ
the King; now the Pri≈øoner was of a Trade that told Tales, and the wicked Mufty ≈øtrongly pre≈øum'd that this was the Man, who had not only often refre≈øh'd his Memory with the mention of his Guilt, but did give him ≈øome di≈øturbance in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his ill-gotten Goods, and therefore he was unpardonable, ≈øuch a Man he could not endure ≈øhould live. But though he knows not how to forgive, yet I heartily wi≈øh he may repent, that God may forgive him, le≈øt he find Hell a more difficult place to get out of than of late he imagin'd.

I ≈øhall pa≈øs by ≈øeveral Circum≈øtances, which perhaps ≈øome would think material, that I may avoid Tediou≈øne≈øs and come to the Tryal it≈øelf, which was begun on Thur≈øday June 1, but re≈øpited till Saturday following, that this bloody Scene might be acted with the greater Solemnity. The Court being ≈øet, ≈øeveral appeared on the Bench, but his real and effectual Judg was Treby, one of the old Republican ≈øtrain, and as fit a Per≈øon as could have been pickt out for ≈øuch a murderous De≈øign; this Man being Recorder of the City of London, when the Lord Ru≈ø≈øel was condemned for High Trea≈øon, and by his place being to pa≈øs Sentence upon him did declare him≈øelf exceedingly troubled in mind and mightily di≈ø≈øatisfy'd becau≈øe there was only one po≈øitive Witne≈øs, and other circum≈øtantial Evidence again≈øt his Lord≈øhip, and not two po≈øitive Evidences to the ≈øame fact, as he ≈øaid the Law required: But ≈øee how mens Con≈øciences can face about, when their Malice is to be gratified; he could now brow-beat, revile, and in effect force a Jury to bring in a Verdict of High Trea≈øon, when there was not one po≈øitive Evidence to any matter of fact, nor indeed any Evidence at all, that could directly affect the Pri≈øoner as to the matter in his Indictment. The Lord deliver me and all hone≈øt Men from Trebyan Ju≈øtice. Herodotus relates of Camby≈øes, that he took an unju≈øt Judge and cau≈øed his Skin to be ≈ølead off, and tann'd, and therewith the Seat of Ju≈øtice to be lined, and then put his Son in the place, who ≈øitting upon his Father's hide, could not want a Monitor to make him careful
to pronounce righteous Judgment; and for my part I cannot give a rea≈øon why Chri≈øtians ≈øhould not be as ≈øollicitous to have Ju≈øtice duly admini≈øtred as Heathens.

Mr. Anderton made it his Reque≈øt, that he might have a Copy of his Indictment, but it would not be granted; and indeed ≈øo great Care was taken, and ≈øo ≈øtrict a Charge given, that neither before nor after his Tryal could any Copy be obtained, ≈øo long as he lived; whether it may be had now I know not. The Crime laid to his Charge was the Compo≈øing, Printing and Publi≈øhing two Malicious Trea≈øonable Libels: The fir≈øt intituled, Remarks upon the pre≈øent Confederacy, and late Revolution in England; The ≈øecond, a French Conque≈øt neither de≈øirable nor practicable. As to the later of the≈øe it is now certainly known, that he had no hand in it, and that it was Printed at a Pre≈øs which he never ≈øaw, and by Per≈øons with whom for a long time he had no Communication: and it mu≈øt be allowed to be a rea≈øonable Suppo≈øal, that his Judge knew this at the time of his Tryal. For the Government had at that time in their cu≈øtody tho≈øe Per≈øons, who knew when and where it was Printed (and as it was ≈øaid) had made a Di≈øcovery of all‚ñ™ perhaps of more than they knew: The Papers of that ≈øort taken upon the Pri≈øoner were ≈øent to him the day before he was ≈øeized; and ≈øome have a vehement ≈øu≈øpicion, that it being re≈øolved he ≈øhould be taken the next day, tho≈øe Pamphlets were ≈øent before hand that ≈øomething might certainly be found upon him: But his Innocence in that Matter hath ≈øince been made evident to all the World by an irrefragable Te≈øtimony; for this September Se≈ø≈øions at the Old Baily, Price in open Court made Oath, that he and the Pri≈øoners then at the Bar, Newbolt and Butler, Printed the French Conque≈øt. This was both a Surpri≈øe and a Choak-pear to ≈øome there, and a murmuring noi≈øe ran through the Court, whil≈øt ≈øome whi≈øper'd, And was Anderton then hanged for that which othes have done? And the Attorney General, a Man who need not be taught to ≈øpeak, was ≈øtruck dumb and look'd blank, I ≈øuppo≈øe in anger and indignation that he ≈øhould be
impos'd upon to accu≈øe a Man of a thing for which he lo≈øt his Life; and the ≈øame Man in the ≈øame Court proved innocent. For this I do think of him that he would not knowingly pro≈øecute a fal≈øe Accu≈øation again≈øt an innocent Man, tho this is more than I would ≈øay of the Judge.

Upon the Tryal the principal Evidence again≈øt the Pri≈øoner was Robin Stephens the Me≈ø≈øenger: Now all Courts of Judicature u≈øe to have a particular regard to the Credibility of the Witne≈ø≈øes, and not to throw away any mans Life upon the Te≈øtimony of infamous malicious Per≈øons; and ≈øuch as care not what they ≈øwear. Now the Man is yet living to bear witne≈øs of it again≈øt whom Robin Stephens in Malice made Oath before a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, that he was a bu≈øie, trouble≈øome Di≈ø≈øenter, came not to his Pari≈øh-Church, nor had received the Sacrament there, for the ≈øpace of Twelve Months then la≈øt pa≈øt, and the Gentleman being brought before the Ju≈øtice of Peace to ≈øatisfy the Law in that ca≈øe, he gave ≈øuch convincing Evidence to the ≈øaid Ju≈øtice that he was a con≈øtant Churchman, and for Eleven of the ≈øaid Twelve Months had received the Sacrament at his own Pari≈øh-Church, that the Ju≈øtice gave him his Warrant to take up Stephens for making a fal≈øe Oath; and the Warrant he lately had to produce, and I believe hath ≈øtill. But what a rare Fellow this is for hone≈øt Mens Lives to depend on, you ≈øhall farther perceive by the Te≈øtimony he gave upon the Tryal.

One thing whereof Mr. Stephens made Oath was, that at the time of Mr. Anderton's Apprehen≈øion, he did in Words di≈øown the Government, and call'd K. W. Hook no≈øe, not ≈øubmitting him≈øelf. Now as to the Words this is ab≈øolutely fal≈øe; for ≈øome ≈øcuffle there was but not a Word ≈øpoken. Mr. Anderton in the time of his Health and Liberty was a Man of Integrity, and ≈øo far from being given to Lying, that he particularly hated a Lyar, and ≈øuch a Per≈øon no one can think would per≈øi≈øt in a needle≈øs Lye at his Death; and to the very la≈øt he denyed the ≈øpeaking any ≈øuch Words; but for a further Evidence he told to ≈øeveral Per≈øons the very rea≈øon of
his Silence. For he ≈øaid he knew Robin Stephens to be ≈øhort-≈øighted, but withal that he knew his Voice, and that while he did not di≈øcover him≈øelf by ≈øpeaking, he was in ≈øome hope to give him the ≈ølip. But if Robin Stephens be plea≈øed a little better to recollect him≈øelf, he may then perhaps remember that another Per≈øon about three days before that time had ≈øaid ≈øuch Words to him; but he ought to have a care how he transfers Matters from one Man to another; for that is the way not only to condemn the innocent, but to acquit the guilty: But after all, ≈øuppo≈øe it true, that he had ≈øpoken that unhand≈øome Word; a di≈øre≈øpectful Term it might be, but Trea≈øon it was not, neither was it any thing to his Indictment; and why then ≈øhould a Judge make ≈øuch a bu≈øtle about it, and exerci≈øe his Wit thence to prove the Pri≈øoner di≈øaffected to the Government? What hath a Judge to do with a Man's Affections? If a Jury will be prevail'd on to find a man guilty of High Trea≈øon for ≈øaying a Man has a Hook-no≈øe, who really has a Hook-no≈øe, they will hang a Man for ≈øpeaking truth; and that is an ill Country for an hone≈øt Man to live in.

Another part of Mr. Stephens's Evidence was, that he there took an old Trunk fill'd with Papers and Pamphlets, and that he had ≈øeen the ≈øaid Trunk formerly, and knew it to be Mr. Anderton's, and le≈øt the poor old Trunk ≈øhould not be ≈øufficiently taken notice of, it is put into the Ordinary's Paper, and al≈øo into that which was cry'd about on the day of his Execution. Now the Rea≈øon of Swearing to the Knowledge of the Trunk was, becau≈øe it was not found in any of the Rooms that could be proved to belong to Mr. Anderton: But if Robin Stephens had never ≈øeen that Trunk before, then he mu≈øt make a fal≈øe Oath in ≈øwearing that he had ≈øeen it before, and that he knew it to belong to Mr. Anderton: and indeed he had never ≈øeen that Trunk before, nor did it belong to Mr. Anderton. For I can name the Gentlewoman to whom the Trunk did belong; and in who≈øe con≈øtant u≈øe it hath been for the≈øe Ten years la≈øt pa≈øt and upwards, in who≈øe hou≈øe Robin Stephens
never was that ≈øhe can tell, nor doth ≈øhe ≈øo much as know him; and ≈øome Weeks before Mr. Anderton's Apprehen≈øion ≈øhe innocently lent the ≈øaid Trunk to a Per≈øon who ≈øaid ≈øhe had occa≈øion for ≈øuch a thing for a little time, and did expect it to have been returned but now ≈øhe mu≈øt lo≈øe her Trunk, and dare not own it, le≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould bring her≈øelf into a great deal of Trouble for doing a common neighbourly Kindne≈øs.

But the Evidence which was principally relyed on, and which ≈øeemed mo≈øt ≈øtrongly to affect the Pri≈øoner, was the matter of the Desk, as to which Robert Stephens made Oath, that he took out of the ≈øaid Desk 40 or 50 of a ≈øort of the Remarks and French Conque≈øts. Now herein lay the great Ma≈øter-piece of Robin Stephens's Villany, for he had ≈øeen the Desk formerly, and might well remember and ≈øwear to the knowledge of it, and moreover the Desk was taken in a room, which was owned to belong to Mr. Anderton; but all this comes ≈øhort; for it is no Trea≈øon to have a Desk, yea even a notoriou≈øly known Desk; and therefore to do the Feat it was requi≈øite, that ≈øome Books ≈øhould be found in that Desk, and then it would be rea≈øonably ≈øuppo≈øed, that the Books did belong to the Owner of it; though this is no infallible Rea≈øoning. For Mens Books, Moneys, and other Commodities, are often laid up in other Mens Desks; every thing is not a Man's own, which he has in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. But the truth is, there was not ≈øo much as one of the Remarks or French Conque≈øts in the ≈øaid Desk; and if after Mr. Anderton was apprehended, Robin Stephens or any of his Gang did ≈øteal the ≈øaid Desk, and put ≈øuch trea≈øonable Papers into it, I would ask of any indifferent Per≈øon, Whether he, or they, or Mr. Anderton ought to be hanged for it? I could name the Per≈øon who hath more than once told me, that when-ever he could appear with ≈øafety, he would be ready to make Oath, That about an hour before Mr. Anderton was ≈øeized he had occa≈øion to look for ≈øomething in the ≈øaid Desk; and that at that time there was nothing in it, but two Quires of clean white Paper, and ≈øome bound Books (i.e. ≈øuch as the Bible,
